repnme.cdata!:
Indonesia - Water supply and sanitation for
            low income communities

abstracts.cdata!:
The Water Supply and Sanitation for
            Low-Income Communities (WSSLIC) project was jointly
            initiated by the World Bank and the Government of Indonesia
            (GOI) in 1993. The project was designed to improve the water
            supply and sanitation conditions in some of the poorest
            rural communities of Indonesia. It was expected that
            improved access to safe and reliable water supply and
            sanitation facilities, along with the provision of hygiene
            and sanitation education would result in improved health and
            increased productivity of the community members. Community
            participation was encouraged in all phases of the project,
            from project design to implementation and maintenance.
            Mechanisms such as meetings, community surveys, focus group
            discussion, training, and capacity-building exercises
            facilitated active community involvement. Information
            sharing and dissemination was ensured through community
            notices and updates on project rules, roles, and
            responsibilities. Such data sharing also induced
            transparency in the project's activities. WSSLIC was
            completed in September 1999 and contributed substantially to
            improve the water supply and sanitation facilities in rural
            communities, although sanitation and hygiene education did
            not result in any major behavioral changes. Some of the
            other issues that remained partially unresolved were
            administrative and fund channeling arrangements, mechanisms
            to encourage the active participation of women, and the
            delegation of community control over the water supply and
            sanitation systems. The Second Water Supply and Sanitation
            Project (WSSLIC 2) began operation in 2000. The project
            builds on the drawbacks and lessons learnt from WSSLIC and
            other rural infrastructure development projects in Indonesia.

Indonesia - Water supply and sanitation for
            low income communities

repnme.cdata!:
Indonesia - Second Jabotabek Urban
            Development Project and the Semarang-Surakarta Urban
            Development Project and the Water Supply and Sanitation
            Project for Low-Income Communities Project

abstracts.cdata!:
The three audits represent OED's
            effort to broaden its customary project audit format to
            include an analysis of the adequacy of the World Bank's
            sector assistance. Besides analyzing each project, the
            cluster audit identifies constraints and recipes for success
            that could apply to the entire Indonesian water supply and
            sewerage sector. The performance audit report demonstrates
            that the focus of future assistance should aim at creating
            appropriate sector legislation, regulation, and policies.
            Such a policy-based assistance strategy would improve the
            development and impact of future lending and reach the
            smaller municipalities where the needs are the greatest. OED
            rates the Second Jabotabek Urban Development Project
            satisfactory, its institutional development impact modest,
            sustainability unlikely, and both Bank and Borrowr
            performance satisfactory. The rating of the
            Semarang-Surakarta Urban Development Project is problematic
            since the two project cities differed widely in all aspects.
            In the weighted summary rating, OED rates the outcome of the
            Semarang-Surakarta project moderately unsatisfactory, its
            institutional development impact modest, sustainability
            unlikely, Bank performance satisfactory, and Borrower
            performance unsatisfactory. Finally, OED rates the outcome
            of the Water Supply and Sanitation in Low-Income Communities
            project satisfactory, its institutional development impact
            substantial, sustainability likely, and both Bank and
            Borrower performances satisfactory.

repnme.cdata!:
Indonesia - Water Supply and Sanitation for
            Low Income Communities Project

abstracts.cdata!:
The project is rated satisfactory, and
            sustainability is likely. Lessons are addressed under three
            categories: underlying theory and assumptions; project
            design; and, project implementation. First, the reasoning
            behind most water supply, and sanitation projects is that
            water is a public good with impact on health, whereas
            sanitation is considered a private good. Though not
            explicit, this implies that while water supply should be
            subsidized (or publicly intervened), sanitation remain a
            personal decision matter, thus the project actively
            challenged sanitary integration through the inclusion of a
            hygiene and sanitation education component, stimulating a
            household package for latrine construction. Second,
            operations like this one, should use simple project design
            schemes, relying on community participation, through proper
            training, and technical support; but, accountability for
            funds allocation, should be centrally channeled,
            particularly if inter-governmental coordination is
            politically, or technically weak. It is emphasized that
            reliable, and timely data collection is required for a
            continuous hands-on operation, and corrective changes,
            avoiding comparable data which may be hindered by variable
            methods. Third, project implementation should consider both
            political, and logistic criteria; ensure monitoring and
            evaluation; and, balance institutional arrangements between
            limited cost overruns, and procedures.

repnme.cdata!:
Indonesia - Water Supply and Sanitation For
            Low Income Communities Project

abstracts.cdata!:
This project provides safe, adequate and
            easily accessible water supply and sanitation services and
            supports hygiene/health education for poor communities in
            underserved and unserved rural villages outside Java and in
            communities around a few densely populated districts in Java
            through sustainable and community-based arrangements.
            Provision of water supply and sanitation (WSS), supported by
            essential hygiene and sanitation education, will improve the
            health status and productivity of the poor communities. The
            project serves about 2 million people living in selected
            rural and urban low-income communities in six provinces.
            Provincial level poverty status is the main consideration
            for selecting these provinces. The project comprises two
            broad components. The first component, water supply,
            provides safe water to about 2 million people in about 1,400
            communities. This includes construction of piped systems
            (spring capture, groundwater, and surface) and non-piped
            systems (protected dug wells, protected springs, shallow and
            deep wells with hand pumps, rainwater collectors, and
            appropriate systems). About 10 percent of the water supply
            component provides for rehabilitation of existing
            facilities. The second component, sanitation, provides
            appropriate sanitation facilities to approximately 1.7
            million people through a process of demonstration, training,
            and promotion to encourage beneficiary and private-sector
            participation in constructing and financing sanitation facilities.
